interactions.description: 4 AM - Jett crying. Jillian got up twice to soothe him. I laid there for 5 min while baby cried. She said thanks for the help sarcastically.
interactions.advice: When you hear the baby at night, get up immediately — even if you're exhausted. The 5-minute delay while she handles it alone speaks louder than words. Consider setting up a schedule (alternate nights) so expectations are clear and no one feels abandoned.

interactions.description: Came home from gym, found her reading. Apologized for not helping with Jett at 4am. Offered to take tomorrow morning shift. Took Jones to school. Made breakfast for family.
interactions.advice: This is exactly the right repair sequence: acknowledge the miss, apologize without excuses, and commit to a specific future action. The acts of service (school, breakfast) reinforce the repair. Keep this pattern — repairs build trust when done quickly and genuinely.

interactions.description: Morning school rush. Light situation - set healthy boundary about always language (good). Coffee spill left ring on wood table - got defensive with logic instead of just owning it and cleaning up.
interactions.advice: The boundary-setting was good leadership. But the coffee defense was a missed opportunity — when something matters to her (the table), logic doesn't help. Next time: 'You're right, I'm sorry' + immediately fix it. Save the explaining for later, if ever.

interactions.description: Took initiative to apologize for getting defensive about the coffee. She explained the table is a sore spot. Apologized for that too. Quick repair, no drama.
interactions.advice: Quick repair after defensiveness is gold. You learned something new (the table is a sore spot) which helps you avoid future friction. This builds safety because she sees you can catch yourself and course-correct without being asked.

interactions.description: Jillian made Joshua a sandwich for lunch. Later she shared a story about her job - Joshua was fully engaged, helped her out, made her laugh. She asked him to put Jett down for a nap and he enthusiastically agreed and did it. She looked very happy.
interactions.advice: This is the ideal pattern: receive her care (sandwich), be fully present when she shares, contribute without being asked (enthusiastic with Jett). Her visible happiness is the clearest signal you're in the right zone. More of this energy.
